Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: The log has multiple case IDs, each representing a process instance. The activities in each case seem to follow a similar sequence but with some variations, especially around the Request Missing Info (RMI) activity which occurs twice in some cases. Also, there's a Validate Form (VF) after RMI, which might indicate re-validation.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 1's activities are RA, VF, AE, RMI, VF, AD, SC, AC. So here, after AE, they do RMI once, then VF again, then proceed. So that's one occurrence of RMI followed by VF.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 3's activities after AE are RMI (9:25), then another RMI (9:45), then VF (10:20). So between the two RMI's, there's no other activity except the second RMI. So perhaps the loop allows multiple RMI steps before exiting, followed by re-validation (VF).

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: If AE is always followed by a loop allowing one or more RMI activities, then exiting the loop with VF makes sense. Analyzing all cases, this loop seems to generalize well: one loop iteration for Case 1, two loop iterations for Case 3, etc.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Testing against the logs: Case 1 has one RMI step (one iteration of the loop), Case 3 has two RMI steps (two iterations of the loop), and Case 2 has one RMI step. All are correctly captured by having a loop after AE with RMI as the body, and exiting the loop before VF.

Name: Pattern Recognition - IND
Text: All cases follow the same path with no branching except the loop for multiple RMI steps. For simplicity, no XOR operator is required, and all activities align linearly without additional decision points.
